Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 502, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 571]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 586]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 628, 90]]<|/det|> A student is investigating moments using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 364, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 880, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 274, 532, 292]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 146, 324]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 920, 355]]<|/det|> The student places the metre rule, without the loads, on the pivot and adjusts its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. She keeps the rule at this position on the pivot throughout the experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 920, 401]]<|/det|> Explain briefly why this position on the pivot may not be exactly at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark of the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 146, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 509]]<|/det|> She places a load P on the metre rule so that the edge that is furthest from the pivot is exactly at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 920, 555]]<|/det|> She measures the distance a between this edge of the load P and the pivot, as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 568, 920, 602]]<|/det|> She places a load Q on the metre rule and adjusts the position of load Q so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 920, 648]]<|/det|> She measures the distance \(b\) between the centre of load Q and the pivot, as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 920, 694]]<|/det|> She repeats the procedure, with the edge of the load P that is furthest from the pivot at the \(15.0 \text{cm}, 20.0 \text{cm}, 25.0 \text{cm}\) and \(30.0 \text{cm}\) marks. All the readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 707, 541, 725]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 739, 645, 892]]<|/det|>
\(a/\text{cm}\)\(b/\text{cm}\)

33.038.5

23.027.2
18.022.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the rate of cooling of water under different conditions. A greater rate of cooling occurs if there is a greater change in the temperature during the same period of time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 504, 137]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 and Fig. 2.2 show the apparatus used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Beaker A has a lid. Beaker B is on a mat made of the same material as the lid. The mat and the lid have the same thickness.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 196, 675, 426]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 440, 532, 459]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 782, 920, 816]]<|/det|>

He places the lid on the beaker and places the thermometer in the beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|> He records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). He immediately starts the stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 897, 183]]<|/det|> He records the time and temperature readings every 30 s until he has six sets of readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 821, 214]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using beaker B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 606, 89]]<|/det|>
The student connects the voltmeter across the lamp L.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 635, 121]]<|/det|>
She records the potential difference \(V_{4}\) across the lamp L.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 129, 917, 153]]<|/det|>
\[V_{4} = \frac{2.5\mathrm{V}}{2.5\mathrm{V}} \quad (2.5V)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 544, 183]]<|/det|>
She calculates the resistance \(R_{4}\) of the lamp L.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 191, 917, 212]]<|/det|>
\[R_{4} = \frac{8.1\Omega}{2.5\Omega} \quad (8.1\Omega)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 920, 275]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the relationship between the thickness of a converging (convex) lens and its focal length. Fig. 4.1 shows the cross-section of a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of a lens can be calculated if \(u\) (the distance between the object and the lens) and \(v\) (the distance between the lens and the image on a screen) are known.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 354, 186]]<|/det|>
The equation is: \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 207, 517, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 408, 532, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4.1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 920, 473]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the relationship between the thickness \(t\) and the focal length \(f\) of converging lenses. You may add to Fig. 4.1 as part of your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 485, 537, 503]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 304, 533]]<|/det|>
illuminated object

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 653, 549]]<|/det|>
selection of lenses of different thicknesses and a lens holder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 213, 564]]<|/det|>
screen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 245, 580]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 579, 250, 596]]<|/det|>
30 cm ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 593, 917, 611]]<|/det|>
two rectangular wooden blocks with the longest sides longer than the diameter of the lenses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 625, 324, 642]]<|/det|>
